datafield.subfield: Edson Read Sunderland, outstanding midwestern legal scholar and professor of law and legal research at the University of Michigan, was associated with the university's law school from 1901 to 1944.

He spent six months studying court procedure in England in the 1920s, becoming a vigorous advocate for reform in legal procedure. He drafted the official forms of pleading adopted by the Supreme Court of Michigan in 1931 and the Illinois Civil Practice Act, which was adopted in 1933.

Sunderland was a member of the United States Supreme Court Advisory Committee which formulated the Federal Rules of 1938 and an honorary member of the bar associations of Chicago, Kansas City, Tennessee, and Pennsylvania. A nationally recognized authority on legal procedure, he authored more than twenty books and 130 articles on related legal issues.

The Edson Read Sunderland collection spans the years 1895 to 1956 with the bulk of the material covering 1930 to 1953. The collection, which is comprised mainly of writings, speeches, research materials, and correspondence, reflects Sunderland's meticulous and focused approach to legal scholarship.

The papers are organized into eight series including Biographical Materials, Speeches and Articles, Research Material and Reports, Organizations and Committees, Correspondence, University of Michigan Law School, Faculty Board in Control of Student Publications, and Miscellaneous Papers. Of particular note and well represented are materials related to Sunderland's research and his speeches and articles. Sunderland wrote prolifically on matters of legal procedure.
